und.safe_value: For emotionally resonant reporting on migrant family separation at the U.S./Mexico border, including haunting audio of detained and distressed children desperate to reunite with their parents.
For commanding and courageous coverage of the murder of Saudi-born journalist and Washington Post contributor Jamal Khashoggi inside Saudi Arabia’s Turkish consulate.

title: Kathleen McGrory and Neil Bedi of the Tampa Bay Times

und.safe_value: For impactful reporting, based on sophisticated data analysis, that revealed an alarming rate of patient fatalities following Johns Hopkins’ takeover of a pediatric heart treatment facility.

title: Aaron Glantz and Emmanuel Martinez of Reveal from The Center for Investigative Reporting, Emeryville, Calif. (in collaboration with Associated Press, PRX and the PBS NewsHour)

und.safe_value: For an exposé of redlining that analyzed more than 30 million mortgage records to uncover discrimination in the banking system, highlighting how skin color still shuts out millions of people from home ownership.

title: Kyra Gurney, Nicholas Nehamas, Jay Weaver and Jim Wyss of the Miami Herald

und.safe_value: For an ambitious explanation of a far-reaching criminal operation in which South American gold mining fueled international money laundering, urban street crime, environmental degradation, child exploitation, drug trafficking and a thriving precious metals industry in Miami.
For exhaustive data analysis and haunting storytelling that revealed the vast number of unsolved homicide cases in America’s major cities.

title: Jill Lepore of The New Yorker

und.safe_value: For critical, yet restrained, explorations of incredibly varied subjects, from Frankenstein to Ruth Bader Ginsburg, that combined literary nuance with intellectual rigor.

title: Deanna Pan and Jennifer Berry Hawes of The Post and Courier, Charleston, S.C.

und.safe_value: For a deeply moving examination of racial injustice in South Carolina that led to the execution of a 14-year-old black boy wrongfully convicted of killing two white girls, and that ultimately exonerated him seven decades after his death.

title: Elizabeth Bruenig of The Washington Post

und.safe_value: For eloquent reflections on the exile of a teen sexual assault victim in the author’s Texas hometown, delving with moral authority into why the crime remained unpunished.
For luminous columns that expertly explore the intersection of gender and politics with a personal, yet keenly analytical, point of view.

title: Melinda Henneberger of The Kansas City Star

und.safe_value: For examining, in spare and courageous writing, institutional sexism and misogyny within her hometown NFL team, her former governor’s office and the Catholic Church.

title: Editorial Staff of the Capital Gazette, Annapolis, Md.

und.safe_value: For deeply personal editorials that reflected on gun violence, loss and recovery following a newsroom attack that left five of the writers’ colleagues dead.

title: Editorial Staff of The Advocate, Baton Rouge, La.

und.safe_value: For persuasive editorials that prompted Louisiana voters to abolish a Jim Crow-era law that undermined equal justice in the jury system.

title: Manohla Dargis of The New York Times

und.safe_value: For authoritative film criticism that considered the impact of movies both inside the theater and in the wider world with rare passion, craftsmanship and insight.

title: Staff of the South Florida Sun Sentinel

und.safe_value: For exhaustive and lucid multi-platform coverage of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School rampage that brought compassion and clarity to a horrific tragedy.

The International Reporting Pulitzer jury chose a New York Times story and accompanying podcast, “Caliphate,” as one of three finalists in the category. In 2020, after Canadian authorities charged a figure profiled in the entry with perpetrating a terrorist hoax, an internal Times investigation concluded that the work failed its "standards for accuracy.” The Pulitzer Prize Board accepted withdrawal of the entry as an appropriate resolution of this matter.

For authoritative coverage of the Trump administration’s migrant family separation policy that exposed a federal government overwhelmed by the logistics of caring for and tracking thousands of immigrant children.

title: Staff of The New York Times, with contributions from Carole Cadwalladr of The Guardian/The Observer of London

und.safe_value: For reporting on how Facebook and other tech firms allowed the spread of misinformation and failed to protect consumer privacy, leading to Cambridge Analytica’s theft of 50 million people’s private information, data that was used to boost Donald Trump’s campaign.
An artful novel that chronicles a mother’s search for her estranged daughter against the backdrop of the AIDS crisis, and contemplates the ripples of grief affecting generations of survivors.
The Great Believers
Viking
A compassionate debut that, through 12 Native American narrators making their way to a California powwow, offers a chorus of voices struggling with questions of identity and authenticity.
There There
Alfred A. Knopf
A morally engaging investigation of torture that measures American ideals of democracy and equality against a dark, uncomfortable reality.
Civilizing Torture: An American Tradition
Belknap Press of Harvard University Press
A beautiful restoration of the world of botanist and surgeon Dr. David Hosack whose forward-looking views embodied early American ambitions in transatlantic scientific discourse.
American Eden: David Hosack, Botany, and Medicine in the Garden of the Early Republic
Liveright/W.W. Norton
A nuanced portrait of CIA operative and foreign policy expert Edward Lansdale that adroitly captures his complex character, misunderstood legacy and the contradictions of his times.
The Road Not Taken: Edward Lansdale and the American Tragedy in Vietnam
Liveright/W.W. Norton
A revelatory work that speaks to the power and influence of three women at the highest levels of French society, whose lives intertwined in the imagination of novelist Marcel Proust.
Proust's Duchess: How Three Celebrated Women Captured the Imagination of Fin-de-Siècle Paris
Alfred A. Knopf
A volume of imaginative, idiosyncratic verse that merges contemporary speech with Middle English tradition to interpret the transgender experience.
feeld
Milkweed Editions
A collection of inventive formal poetry that challenges, gives shape to, and delights in how the art form mimics and distorts the universalities of life.
Like
Farrar, Straus and Giroux
A rigorously reported story about American vulnerability to rising seas, particularly disenfranchised people with limited access to the tools of rebuilding.
Rising: Dispatches from the New American Shore
Milkweed Editions
An unembellished series of case studies about sexual violence exacted on mostly immigrant women in America, many toiling in a shadow economy.
In a Day’s Work: The Fight to End Sexual Violence Against America’s Most Vulnerable Workers
The New Press
A charming and incisive analysis of gender and racial biases inherent to the U.S. Constitution that examines how this living document could evolve to fit modern America.
What the Constitution Means to Me
A refreshingly unorthodox play that conveys the joy and abandon of dancing, while addressing the changes to body and mind of its preteen characters as they peer over the precipice toward adulthood.
Dance Nation
Released by New World Records, a hypnotic solo-piano work comprised of 43 individual sections whose striking harmonic implications and subtly dramatic effects distill music to its barest essences.
Still

Premiered by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, an absorbing orchestral work rich with mesmerizing textures and color, including washes of clustered string sounds and cascading winds, creating a virtual sound installation in which perceptions of time are suspended (Schott Music).
Sustain

title: Ken Fisher, drawing as Ruben Bolling, freelancer

und.safe_value: For pointed political commentary, informed by comics history, that provided readers nuanced satire of the Trump phenomenon.
For provocative illustrations that channeled cultural and historical references with expert artistry and an eye for hypocrisy and injustice.

title: Brandon Stahl, Jennifer Bjorhus, MaryJo Webster and Renée Jones Schneider of the Star Tribune, Minneapolis, Minn.

und.safe_value: For an illuminating and disturbing series that exposed breakdowns in Minnesota’s investigation and prosecution of rape cases, and how such ineptitude fails victims of sexual assault.

title: Barbara Laker, Wendy Ruderman, Dylan Purcell and Jessica Griffin of The Philadelphia Inquirer

und.safe_value: For dogged scientific investigation and evocative storytelling that exposed toxic dangers lurking in Philadelphia school buildings that sickened children in their classrooms.

title: Staff of the Chico Enterprise-Record in collaboration with the Bay Area News Group

und.safe_value: For committed coverage of an epic California wildfire that consumed more than 18,000 buildings in 150,000 acres, and took 86 lives. (Moved by the jury from Local Reporting, where it was originally entered.)
For searing images that chronicled clashes between Palestinians and Israelis in the Gaza Strip.

title: Noah Berger, John Locher and Ringo H. W. Chiu of Associated Press

und.safe_value: For devastating images that chronicled the historic 2018 fire season in California and captured the destruction from massive blazes as they spread at an extraordinary pace

title: Craig F. Walker of The Boston Globe

und.safe_value: For superb photography and sophisticated visual storytelling that brought understanding to the story of a young boy living with a complex developmental disability.

title: Maggie Steber and Lynn Johnson of National Geographic

und.safe_value: For a compelling, dignified photo narrative that provides an intimate look at the youngest face transplant recipient in the U.S.

title: David Barstow, Susanne Craig and Russ Buettner of The New York Times

und.safe_value: For an exhaustive 18-month investigation of President Donald Trump’s finances that debunked his claims of self-made wealth and revealed a business empire riddled with tax dodges. (Moved by the Board to the Explanatory Reporting category.)
